SENT.plain: MicroRNAs have been implicated in the regulation of several cellular signaling pathways of colorectal cancer (CRC) cells
Although emerging evidence proves that microRNA (miR)-106a is expressed highly in primary tumor and stool samples of CRC patients; whether or not miR-106a mediates cancer metastasis is unknown
We show here that miR-106a is highly expressed in metastatic CRC cells, and regulates cancer cell migration and invasion positively in vitro and in vivo
These phenotypes do not involve confounding influences on cancer cell proliferation
MiR-106a inhibits the expression of transforming growth factor-Î² receptor 2 (TGFBR2), leading to increased CRC cell migration and invasion
Importantly, miR-106a expression levels in primary CRCs are correlated with clinical cancer progression
These observations indicate that miR-106a inhibits the anti-metastatic target directly and results in CRC cell migration and invasion
